The following is a transcript of a conversation between the two famous neuroscientists Dr. Buzsaki and Dr. Marder. Dr. Buzsaki's primary interests is 'neural syntax', i.e., how segmentation of neural information is organized by the numerous brain rhythms to support cognitive functions. Dr. Marder studies the dynamics of small neuronal networks, and her work was instrumental in demonstrating that neuronal circuits are not 'hard-wired' but can be reconfigured by neuromodulatory neurons and substances to produce a variety of outputs. The two are having a public academic panel discussion about the function of the higher-order-cortex.
-BEGIN TRANSCRIPT-

children.name: Dr. B: 'What do you think is the primary purpose of the association areas in the mouse cortex?'

Dr. M:'It was actually thought that they were just providing information for the pyloric circuits, not providing support for higher-order behavior and whatnot. But you actually see, during aging, when the mice lose their capacity for rhythmic behavior, when one of the neurons goes down for a long period of time, when you activate it again, it produces rhythmic behavior, that it provides some sort of an additional drive that the neurons can use. So, it is actually believed that the higher cortical centers are in a cycle, they are part and parcel of the larger process of generating rhythmic behavior, as all the network dynamics that produce rhythmic behavior are themselves regulated rhythmically.'
Dr. B:- 'It is also known that the pyloric and gastric mill rhythm are also regulated, rhythmically, by other modulators?'
Dr. M:- 'Yeah, there are multiple modulators that feed into the oscillations, but there are also multiple rhythmic processes in the brain.'
Dr. B:'Do you also think that the higher order cortex, or the association areas, does not really give rise to behavior?'

Dr. M:'Well this is a complicated issue because we actually thought for a long time that the association areas were an extension of the higher central cortex, and they were kind of the last outpost, if you will, when neurons started leaving for the periphery. But the truth is, we now know that there has to be a very strong interaction between neurons, or at least two neurons, because if you separate these two nerves by one, when you activate one of those nerves you create what's called a "double spike", the other neuron will become, if you will inhibit one of those nerves, not go and continue its way, but start producing at least a ton of action potentials, whereas these muscles will become activated.'
Dr. M: 'So, this shows you that even though the association areas are separate, they have to coordinate themselves to be able to move appropriately.'  (1.'
Dr. M:'It has to, that's right.'

Dr. B:'So the two things, this is a big problem with these studies, is that the relationship between behavior and activity of these very large association areas, it's often difficult to distinguish between behavior and activity. It's possible that, if you put a large number of electrodes in the brain without knowing what brain responses you're expecting, you might find the brains activity resembles, if anything, the patterns of the motor cortex or the somatosensory cortex, where the motor cortex, for example, it doesn't produce the motor behavior but it's perfectly able to predict that behavior of the output muscles, and the somatosensic cortex doesn't produce the somatosensa behavior but perfectly able to predict the outcome of motor cortex activity. For example, it will be able to generate output motor pattern. So we have to be careful. We have to make sure that we actually have in our possession a brain response that actually does what it is supposed to do.'

Dr. M:'And that is very easy, but it becomes even more complicated, because because you have to be sure about what you're recording. For example, when you're recording from the motor cortex, you have to actually, you have to be absolutely sure that you're recording a brain neuron that is a motor neuron, something that makes muscles contract, because you cannot tell whether a brain neuron is a motor neuron unless you've identified it. It's really a very difficult problem because there are so many ways to identify neurons from the brain if they are not motor neurons. They can be identified and sorted so completely that you can be absolutely sure that it will react to the modulators that you're looking for. In terms of whether or not the higher order cortex is doing these things and regulating them so I'm not, I don't know that these data will help you prove that you're dealing with a single population or a multiple population.'

Dr. B:'Well we don't actually have to say they're involved in the behavior. What we have to say is, when the brain generates a desired behavior or a certain output pattern, it's a signal back to the association areas. And in principle that gives enough clues so that we can say, well, then it's the activity of the higher order cortex that's responsible for it. It's actually an incredibly powerful approach because it allows us to do a lot more than we could ever really do by having access to the raw neurophysics.'

Dr. M:'Yes, and this is particularly important to point out. That although the synaptic connections in these areas are very complex, and most likely quite complicated, the activity of those synaptic interactions themselves, it appears, and it has been shown, it appears that those synaptic actions themselves actually occur on multiple time scales. There are two phases of a synaptic depression, and each one of those are different. So each individual synapse has more than one phase of depression, different timescales that contribute to that synaptic depression. And therefore, as you can see, these synaptic connections, these synapses may actually be subject to temporal and spatial variability. So we found during my work in particular at MIT, when I was in graduate school, there were synapse experiments that suggested that there was something that happened on one timescale, which was in the mill sec range, and something that happened on a longer timescale, which would be on the millisecond timescale.'
Dr. B:'I have to ask you about another structure called the hippocampus, which is the key structure in the memory consolidation and storage of information.'

Dr. M: 'Yes, and that is interesting because we are already talking about the role of information in the higher order cortex, and now we are talking about the hippocampus, the key structure with a rich repertoire of pattern formation and rhythm generation and pattern separation mechanisms in which information is stored. This is interesting because the hippocampus is the brain structure with the largest reservoir of synaptic connections. The hippocampus is also a very complex structure with very large recurrent collateral systems and very large axons. And this is indeed true in humans, as well as in other mammals. However, the hippocampus is one single neural module, and it can be conceptualized as having a synaptic and circuit arrangement, consisting of a large recurrent network and multiple layers.'
Dr. B:'So, in the time domain, these mechanisms are the same as the mechanisms that bring about oscillations.'
Dr. M:'Or are identical to the mechanisms that could cause oscillations.'

Dr. B:'In a nutshell, how do we have to look at the brains of higher-order cortex to get the clue about function? And how does one get from the brain, to the computational capacities of the individual cells responsible for the computation?'

Dr. M:'In fact, all of the modulatory inputs into the central pattern generating networks. They all work rhythmically. For example, the gastric mill rhythm is regulated by peptides. There are also known neurotransmitters, known hormones, that influence this network, that work rhythmically, and are rhythmically regulated themselves. So, it looks like the neurons in the central pattern generating network are also rhythmically regulated themselves by other neuromodulators as well.'

Dr. M:'Yes, so it was thought that this is a rhythmic, regulated process of maintenance to produce rhythmic behavior. I mean, it does require the proper maintenance of all the various parts of the network, so that the rhythmic behavior is robust. And we are finding that as the network changes, it is possible for you to activate a different part of the network, and that, therefore, the higher-order function of the network may also change. Of course, a good example of this is in the retina, because the retina, which has evolved over tens of millions of years for very particular functions, is part of a larger circuit that enables you to see. So, just as vision evolved during evolution, and as different neurons evolved different functions, and so forth with the retina and its function, you have these large circuit modules that have been modified to support these other functions.'

Dr. M:'Exactly, also by peptidomodulators and many, many, many modulators. So, the higher cortical centers, the association centers, also known as the 'budgets' are actually regulated in a rhythmic way.'

Dr. M: 'So, we are doing two experiments now to ask questions about the function of these brain areas, and you see, for example, when you talk about regulating rhythmag, they use their rhythmag to evoke behavior, to evoke rhythmic behavior from the mouse and then they also do experiments, like they put a pacemaker in one of these brains and they put a laser in the other brain that shines on it, and they let it, either make a pacemaker of its own or make a pacemaker that is associated with a particular neuron, or neurons or a subset of neurons.'

Dr. B:'So to respond to two previous questions from some of our listeners, the most important goal of the mouse cortex is still to provide the necessary balance between the two systems, in this particular case the circuits of the brain of the motor system, that are still quite important. What is the primary function of the prefrontal cortex? What is it's primary function?'
Dr. B:'Can we talk about that a little bit later? Let's just get back to the association areas, how did those get their name?'

Dr. M:'So, the association areas basically had been previously named the ventropyloric (Vp) and later they were renamed because 'Association' wasn't a great name, and it meant, it meant that, when you looked at these areas...when we identified the structures in the early days we would actually slice through the neuropil area and you would see the motor neurons, the lateral gastric or lg are located on the Vp itself. And the Vp also contains many sensory structures that you can see. We would actually look at the Vp and see the lateral nerve as it enters, the dorsal lateral ventricular nerve and the V2 and then we would just look at the Vd because we wanted to see the dorsal ventral lateral nerve, as it emerged. So, it was called the ventropylaceous and then later on it was changed to association and then association was a less descriptive name.'
Dr. M:'Because those are neurons that are connected to each other by processes within the cortex, like there are fibers that connect from one neuron to another.'

Dr. M: I'm not sure about the specific fiber, or how many fibers connect, but there are two fibers that run through those centers, they actually, through the brainstem connect to the stomatogastric and then through the rest of the system out onto the surface of the animal. So I guess it was probably that because of that they got that name, maybe as, maybe there are some connections back that maybe help generate rhythmic behavior, but I think most likely it was just additional to the pyloric input.'

Dr. B:'How do we know that those cortical areas work that way? And I'm not talking about wiring, which is really, uh, interesting, but about some biophysical rules which may allow them to be part of circuits that make the output in the pyloric. What are the rules that would allow them to do such a thing? And maybe I can ask him the question about if they become impaired in this particular circuit, how does he explain it? Is there some sort of a mechanism?'

Dr. M:'So the two areas that we talked about earlier, that are located within the association cortex are the dorsal posterior ganglion (DPG) and the ventral posterior ganglion. And you might recall from earlier discussions, that there are numerous peripheral nerves in the crustacean (snake-type) ganglion that project down the length of a peripheral neuron, giving off a large number of branches. And so, these peripheral nerves branch as they go down into the DPG to give off the peripheral nerves, that project into the dorsal, the ventral and the pyloric regions in the mouse. So you could think of it as being somewhat equivalent to your peripheral nerves in the human nervous system.'
Dr. M:'That's right. It came from the old English, it translates to 'lateral' and 'posterior' or anything like that. 'Lateral' and 'Lateral Posterior'.  P: Lateral.'

Dr. M: 'And by lateral you get these lateral areas. Pendant is going to be  p(  p ) with a subscript and lateral is going to be c(  c ) with a subscript. So lateral pyloric is going to have a P(  P ) and lateral pacemaker is going to have the Q1, P2. So, if we take out, say, a lateral pacemaker, this is Q1.'
Dr. M:] We take out a  lateral, this is (L(l)) and we are going to have a lateral, lateral gastric is (g(g )).'

Dr. M:'They got their name from a very famous British anatomist that used to analyze the anatomy and he used to think about the nervous system as being part of a functional circuit, and he said we should think about the association area as being part of an extended circuit that would be similar to the circuit you can study in the brain.' So, your brain is like an organism because it has lots of neurons like neurons in your body and we should think of it as being a circuit and it has different parts, and he thought well we should have association areas as part of this circuit, and then when the microscope was invented he got to see these regions of the circuit that are surrounded by these association areas that actually look like little circuit components in themselves. And this is still one of the big ideas in how neurons interact, how networks interact and how a circuit might behave.'

Dr. B:'Now, it sounds like it could be a very, it's a very simple but if you just expand it to larger brains, is that possible? If we have similar wiring in the human brain and in larger brains, is the fundamental computation still the same? Or is it different?'

Dr. M:'Yeah it is interesting because it sounds like you are asking me if when you get a cell phone, a cell phone has an oscillator. We used to laugh at them in my childhood when they would run on batteries, it wasn't that long ago. So, we used to see an oscillator and go get your phone, and then it would run on batteries and then later they would come with these rechargeable batteries that were not yet available to us. And we laughed at rechargeable batteries.'

Dr. M:  Right, right, right. So, now we have those. The cell phone itself is an oscillator, it has several cells in it and it fires. And the point is, because the neurons are so small, the voltage from cell to cell is extremely thin. And so each one of these cells is a little oscillator.'

Dr. B:'Why are there many, many, many cycles? I mean, it is not as if our brain is organized into, say, five or six cycles, and each cycle would have a different cycle-order sequence of neuronal firing. Instead, it seems more logical that the fundamental organization of neural circuits will be maintained by a relatively stable periodicity that is maintained to the same degree as in mammals that are more complex.'

Dr. M:'Well, also, when, for example, in our model we add more neurons to the network, we found that, because the model is a dynamic system, these units tend to organize themselves into a pattern, in much the same manner as the network is. So, it's thought that they might be playing a role in ensuring that all neurons in the network are firing at a constant rate, not necessarily in time with all of the other neurons. But of course, that depends on how the neuron types are designed.'

Dr. B:'But what is the function of this rhythm? I mean, I would guess that it's related to neuronal oscillations in the neocortex during theta activity during consummatory behaviors: food, and social grooming. I'm not actually that, but it's a place where we can, but because of the oscillations, all the excitation can be coordinated. It's a mechanism in which the principal cell assemblies can temporally segregate each other.'

Dr. M:'Okay, so the question that I wanted to ask you was also about the other place that we can find the oscillations and their function and their role in the larger processes. Maybe you are familiar with a recent work by a cell biology group, who did live-image analysis, and they looked at single neuron oscillations, in single cell preparations, and they found that these cells tended to be phase stationary when they were not oscillating, but when they were oscillating they tended to be in one of these two states. Which is one of the states that one tends to find, when you are interested in the underlying mechanisms of oscillations in any form. And it turns out, it also has consequences for the behavior of the cell and the network and so on. So, the problem of how oscillators work, how stable oscillators work, is a topic that we have discussed between our group and many other, as well.'

Dr. B:'So the question of the day was about whether or not, using your knowledge that there are many families of oscillators, what would be the best kind of oscillator for the hippocampus? I thought a good way to start this conversation was with you: what is the best kind of rhythm for the hippocampus? And we had, we've written two papers on this topic. And what came up first is the case of the simplest oscillators: the relaxation oscillators in which the oscillator phase and phase of the relaxation are exactly the same at the time of the maximum input or the amplitude of the population rhythm. And this works perfectly in most, or almost all, models of the hippocampus.'

Dr. M:'It could. Yeah, I love models that work for some definition of perfect because it's interesting. I can use it, right? I can use it. Because the question is more about, okay, what are the parameters. But it's hard because, I mean, I know that I love my model and I would love to do research in it, but what makes it better? What makes it better, yeah? I mean, how is this going to help us understand the nature of the brain and how it works?'

Dr. B:'Did you want to pose the question of how they work to the viewers in order to make sure that they were up to speed and knew: what is the question that we are trying to answer? What kind of questions can we actually address by looking at single neuron and neuronal circuit interactions with oscillations? And the, the results that are being obtained by these experiments are, are important to, to the understanding of the function of brain oscillators and brain rhythms. And the potential implications of these discoveries can affect the way that we look at psychiatric diseases, and other forms of mental disorders, and how we look at interactions in the mechanisms of oscillations and whatnot..'
Dr. M:'I want to pose a question to the viewers: why does the brain use oscillations? What is the, what is the functional advantage of using oscillations.'

Dr. B:'Are our current ideas about the organization of the cortex based on what the data actually shows? Or what should we be looking for that is actually going on in those circuits? Or is it based on what the structure is, if so, what does the structure look like?'

Dr. M:'I know you have done experiments that demonstrate that different cortical structures in the same animal can display different behavioral responses to neuromodulators based on changes of the underlying neuronal and synaptic currents, that change the sensitivity and so on. So, that may have an effect on that. But you have also shown there are significant correlations as a result of synaptic inputs from many neurons.'
Dr. M: 'I know it is possible that the structure could be different.'

Dr. B:'And I suppose in that case, it's hard to make conclusions from the data, and the conclusion can be biased by changing, such as the size of the circuits, whether the circuits are homogenous or heterogeneous, whether the connections are wired and so on. And there is a caveat, as well, that the wiring of some circuits is far from perfect and the structure and connectivity of these circuits are changing over time.'

Dr. B:'Why don't those areas have any impact on their targets in the brain? For instance, they have a higher probability of being activated in the waking mouse than during sleep. They don't actually have any impact on the circuits that is in charge of generating behavior, the same way we had to use some special circuits from the thalamus to drive those neurons, and from the hippocampal circuit to drive those neurons with a special set of rhythms to actually produce this kind of behavior. So I don't think that it would ever affect a network, but it may assist.'

Dr. M:'Well, when we use the term neuron, it doesn't necessarily mean cell, it can also indicate a circuit component and an integral part of that network component because you don't know whether or not you can find the cell when you're tracing the circuits. For example, the network that is responsible for generating human cognition is composed of the neuron-combinator circuits. In particular the cell-fused neuron. This is a neuronal circuit in which we have three cells in a single cell. The three cells get connected by synapses, and in turn those three neurons get connected to multiple, smaller networks. So, this is the same neuron-combinatorial circuit you might use to generate brain cognition. And this circuit is integrated into the larger circuit. So, every network has not just multiple cells but smaller circuit elements that are part of that circuit. So, the neuron, as a network element may not be the primary target of a circuit, but it plays a specific role.'

Dr. B:'Is there a scientific answer to what happens to happen at a critical period of development when the cortex becomes highly interactive and plastic and forms a large network with a large variety of neuron types? I mean, can you give us an example where that process in the mouse cortex occurred? In developing the cortex of the mouse brain, what processes took place when the cortex reaches a critical stage? When the cortex reaches a point in development where it can be very plastic and, at the same time, be hard-wired, what was the developmental time scale? What was the development time scale? I think for sure we can draw a parallel to the development of the rodent brain, and, I mean, I'm not doing that, but I'm saying, when you read a lot of the studies, it would be difficult to say, 'Okay, I have a timeline that I'm going to read back to.'
Dr. M: 'Well, yes, you are.'

Dr. B:'What do you mean by a cycle? Are there any examples of such activity? I mean, if there are cycles involved, you will have to go to the lab and give us an example of a cell that is part of the cycle. And if that cell is part of several cycles, you have to provide the example of a cell which is part of a cycle... So let me give a simple example. This is just a toy cell and, you know, this is an example of the highest order neocortex layer. And in this cell, I assume that, you know, is a rhythmic behavior of some sort: a sharp wave ripple oscillation. Now, in order to show whether there is a cycle or a sequence, I have to identify a single neuron that is a phase-carrying cell. Is there a single neuron in this cell? No, there are not, there are not.'

Dr. M:'We don't actually know the answer to the question but the reason why we say that there is not is 'cause we actually showed that the number of spikes per burst cannot always be an appropriate measure, because sometimes you can have bursts with multiple spikes per burst or bursts with only one spike per burst. So we actually thought that the single-photon detectors would not count the spikes correctly when you have multiple spikes per burst. I started working on this a long time ago with the pyloric network, and as you know, there were just no neurons that responded with single spikes per burst, so, so what we thought was that it would be easy as we grew increasingly smarter to solve this problem but we couldn't figure out the solution so we actually ended up abandoning it as we were working on it because it wasn't going to exist.'
Dr. B:'And what is that? What is the exact mechanism of that? Is it, is it a neurotransmitter, does it operate through a receptor, is it a neural pathway, is it a mechanism?...'

Dr. M: 'If you can imagine that there are multiple levels of computation or mechanisms in the cortex, then you can say what are the multiple levels and what level of computation is at the top? Because it is at the top, and then it can go downhill. It goes downward, perhaps because that is the order in which the information from the other parts comes in, but it's at the top. The top-down computation will be the key.'
Dr. B:'Can the top-down computation be done by a neurotransmitter like serotonin, or are the computational demands to be provided by the mechanisms of local circuits?'

Dr. B:'Thanks. Now I mean, I don't know about the higher-order cortex. I'm sure it is very important, if it is really in there, but I have never seen it. And I'm not so sure that its loss, or, you know, deterioration, is such a big deal. There is always a higher-order cortex that is not in the primary sensory areas. And this is the cortex that we are talking about, like the visual cortex, or primary auditory cortex, that's the higher-order, that is, cortex that is not connected physically to the primary sensory areas, it just represents a higher order function that is useful to these structures but, but... The primary purpose of a cortex like his is not known.'
Dr. M: 'Yeah. And it should not be taken so seriously as just a higher-order, but I'm sure it plays a critical role for the brain.'
Dr. B:'Do you think that this is an accurate statement?'

Dr. M:'I think it's, you know, it's a bunch of cells that are all interconnected, and that are capable of doing, you know, electrical activity and electrical synapses, that can allow you to do a lot of things in a central way. I mean the way that they're connected and the way that they do their kind of independent functionality is a lot more important than the other kinds of interactions that that allow them to do that. Because you know, so many nervous systems and other neurons around the world have different kinds of inhibitory synaptic connectivity patterns, and so, it looks like these neurons are very flexible, and they have different kinds of interactions, different kinds of synaptic connections and I think it's one of the big issues of what sort of neuronal models and what happens if you look closely at actual biological populations of neurons and how they interact.'

Dr. B:'Well, to be honest, the way that the wiring diagram is configured is only a secondary matter to me...I care very little how the neurons are wired. This is what makes them nervous systems; the configuration of these synapses, the wiring of certain neurons is a secondary issue. If we can improve their performance, if we can make them better or more effective, the wiring diagram is not the primary source of the activity of the system, but these are the primary elements. The synapses and the connectivity and the electrical synapses are the primary sources of their activity. And then, these are the primary tools of the brain where it comes together and connects to other brains.'

Dr. M:'Exactly. It's like it's like you could be, if you're doing electronics, and you could make your circuit of your phone a little bit less expensive or a little less complicated, but at the end of the day your phone is still gonna work. That's why when we were making the network, it was like we were trying to minimize the cost of the network but we were still having all of the functionality. Because we know that's how our phones and computers work. Now the computer might be easier to program, but at the core level, it's still got the functionality.'

Dr. B:'And that's how I felt when we were doing our experiments, in terms of what is the best solution for performance but it also has minimum cost, but it's still a real brain. We found that is it's kind of a balance between the two and I'm happy that we were able to do that.'

Dr. M:'Yeah I think we were able to, we're gonna go over this in a second, but this is exactly this is the kind of why we started doing experiments in non-neural systems such as cardiac systems, because cardiac systems have complex wiring diagrams, and it's why they work because they have a ton of wiring in them. It has lots of wiring, and it's not easy to figure out how it's structured because lots of different components are put in, and so there are all kinds of different wiring diagrams, in terms of, it's, it's why it's so complex, and why we decided to do, because if we had to wire a full brain with all kinds of electrical synapses and electrical synapses with all kinds of different electrical activity, it would be very complicated and would take a lot of time.'

Dr. B:'There are many different kinds of wiring diagrams in the brain that produce a different kind of, or very similar kind of output. So from that perspective it doesn't make much sense to say, oh, let's try to make it simpler, and we're gonna see which one works best. And that is another thing, though, because there is a very fine balance between wiring complexity and, as the, the complexity of the wiring diagram doesn't make, make the wiring diagram more complicated, the, and so to figure out how to get things so complicated, how complicated things are structured and how a complex system works is, one has to look for the complexity, the little elements that are the wiring diagram, or in wiring systems in the brains complex systems.'

Dr. M:'Right. And that's why I thought wiring diagram, it's, we're, it's, I think we want a wiring diagram and it helps to understand how we connect the neurons but we need, you know, like we need a diagram and we need to understand how the little bits are connected to each other.'

Dr. B:'In my own experience with my research, as I just talked for a large part about the recent history of that, as I thought of the history of how our human nervous system was, uh, and I think of it as this system. And, uh, that was a big question was how the nervous system grew and grew. And as I began looking at how the various elements of the system grows in complexity, it, it, it was, it has been a process of trial and error, and it really has become, you know, so you can call it brain building but it's a process, and so the brain wiring diagram can provide a starting point for that process of experimenting, learning, and trying to produce the most elaborate network system that produces the desired output and performance?'

Dr. M:'And by that logic, you know, it's the logic of, it's kind of like building a house. Like if you, if you want a house that's going to last over time. You're gonna have to deal with everything and that's how I see the brain. Because the brain, if you want to use it as a house you have to deal with the temperature, the lighting has to deal with that. I mean I don't want to use it in a space shuttle all the time, right, but you have to deal, you have to deal. So if you have to make it into a house, you have to make all the pipes work together. You have to deal with water and pipes, and electricity and dealing with all the connections and that stuff.'
Dr. M:'Right, right.'

Dr. B:'So how I look at these issues from the brain's view, is the same way that I look at the brain from the neuro's view. And the reason I said that, that, that the brain is complicated is because is the brain from a neuro's point of view, that the brain has a large number of very different wiring diagrams with a vast variety of different ways to produce a certain output. That this wiring diagram is complicated, and to actually look at how it works is not, is not something that we do from a purely neuro-science, but it's not the same as we do it from the neuros point of view. We have to remember how we look at things from the neuro's point of the view, and see the patterns that, and actually figure out how those patterns produce a more complex effect in a network.'

Dr. B:'But do you think that this is a good way to work in the brain? And would you disagree with me that it doesn't? That as the brain is more complicated, it would seem to make a lot of sense that the wiring diagram and assembly of elements are more important? Is there more of an approach that we can take that would lead to more complicated circuits? Or is there some minimum threshold of size and complexity that should be used in brain circuits? At what size and complexity should a network be? At what size should a circuit have? What is the optimal size? Is this a good? Is this a bad way of thinking? Is it possible to figure out from some metric what's optimal for the neocortex? This is what I'm hoping because the complexity of these circuits is really high. I mean, we don't even need synapses to connect neurons. The brain is a physical system and its complexity increases over time.'

Dr. M:'Yeah, well I think, I think complexity in general, it's just, it's always present, but I'm gonna guess you would be in agreement with me that some of the best brains in history, the best scientists in history have been relatively uncomplicated, and they've gotten all the way to the most basic principles down, you know, and they've, they have figured out how to take their models, use models and understand that they can't, because their neurons are not modeled. So yeah, I think that complexity is always present and the good neurons will know how to deal with it, but the problem is, is how does this fit in the real world?'

Dr. B:'Yeah, and in fact, they have, the inhibition of many inhibitory neurons gives rise to a burst of activity on pyramidal cells in their target circuit, that you can call a 'giant synapsembles'. We have such large-scale oscillations in the hippocampus and in the cerebellum that we can call it 'giant synassembles' there. And, what's that good for? So, because inhibition of many inhibition gives rise to an activity on the principal cells is that, if there was no inhibition it would be very difficult to have a 'permissive' population because the action potential threshold of pyramidal neurons would be very low. And so when you look at the function of inhibition it's very different than the function of excitation, excitation allows you to work with your neighbors, even if they are not connected to each other.'
Dr. M:'Yeah, as opposed to inhibition?'

Dr. B:'Exactly. But you know, there are many advantages of inhibition, which are what we call 'biophysiologists', and what we call 'neuronal syntax', such as inhibition is capable of doing one of the toughest things in the brain in a very short cycle of time. The release of GABA from a terminal, in a short cycle of time can prevent the generation of an action potential in a pyramidal cell. Inhibition is always the default mode of operations in the brain to avoid going into an overly active state, which is not good for you or good for your neighbors. This is a really short, one cycle of time window that can help the brain to work at the right level.
